Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Emergence of New Capital Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Capital markets finance domestic infrastructure projects and national enterprises. They include stock and bond markets that channel wealth from savers and investors to borrowers, such as large corporations and governments. Capital markets also move financing across national borders, as when investors buy bonds originated outside their countries of origin. But domestic capital markets are not evenly developed across different market contexts. Various factors impact the development of these markets in any one context, such as the generation of large pools of capital, the relative ease of currency convertibility, and standardized methods for rating credit and risk. The research supported by this award will advance our understanding of these factors as either facilitating or impeding the development of capital markets in specific contexts. This is significant, since reductions in aid and multilateral funding have led to a rise in new forms of debt-financing. By analyzing the development of debt instruments and their mobilization across borders, the research will provide insights for policy debates regarding the aims of financial regulation.

This study hypothesizes that the successful development of new capital markets depends on: 1) the generation of large pools of capital in local currencies and ease of currency convertibility; 2) the production of standardized data sets for credit-scoring, risk-pricing, and asset-class creation; and 3) the role of regulatory policy. This hypothesis contrasts with approaches to global finance that assume the frictionless movement of finance capital. Instead, the research provides an empirical account of how financialization happens in new markets so as to document the ways it is both achieved and constrained. The field sites for this study represent a soft-currency context in which hypotheses about the development of cross-border financial markets can be readily tested. The hypothesis will be tested through a multi-sited ethnography of constituent building blocks: banks and fintech platforms that collect the local currency deposits of savers; institutional investors that mobilize deposits into financial markets; and the exchanges on which financial instruments are traded. The research results will provide a detailed account of these emergent capital markets by examining the extent to which they generate investment-grade financial products that motivate investment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded research advances our understanding of the contemporary geographies of transnational finance. It does so by examining the building blocks of domestic capital markets in Sub-Saharan Africa. In Africa, these financial markets are nascent. However, as multilateral funding and foreign direct investment have diminished over the past decade, both African governments and financial professionals seek to develop domestic capital markets, denominated in local currencies. The advent of financial technologies (fintech) creates new opportunities for financial intermediation, which is the focus of the research. The study establishes whether fintech-enable scaling results in increased intra-African and international payments and transfers, leading to increased demand deposits in local currencies – the basis of domestic capital markets. Empirical study in indicates that: 1) fintech platforms have facilitated an exponential increase in official (i.e., formally documented) remittance transactions over the past decade; and 2) fintech platforms facilitate both peer-to-peer and business-to-business multi-currency cross-border payments. Does this result in an increase in local-currency demand deposits in the commercial banking system? The findings indicate that there is no direct relationship between increased remittance transfers and increased local-currency banking deposits. Fintech platforms do not necessarily engender increased commercial demand deposits in local currencies because the primary modality of transfer is mobile money (e-value on digital wallets), often held on digital wallets and not converted to local currency for deposit. This indicates that fintech platforms do not necessarily ‘bank the unbanked,’ as is generally assumed, a significant conclusion that corrects erroneous assumptions about the nature of financialization – or the premise that financial practices migrate, or are imported without friction, across international boundaries.

The research findings also shed light on an oft-overlooked specificity of the digital technology ecosystem in Africa: the role of telecommunications companies, in contrast to big tech or commercial banks. In Africa, most domestic and cross-border transactions transpire through digital wallets and mobile money, which are the products of licensed subsidiaries created by the telecoms. Therefore, to understand the impact of the fintech ecosystem on the national commercial banking system, one must first understand how value is created by this nexus of telecoms, nonbank subsidiaries, and digital payment services. Study of this nexus represents an innovation in research on financial technologies in the global south, which typically focuses on financial inclusion. The findings indicate not only that fintech platforms don’t bring the unbanked into the financial system, but also that transaction fees are not the main source of value in this ecosystem. Instead, there are two main sources of value for local financial operators. First, value is generated at the interface of e-money and fiat money, or in the form of a “float” that represents digital wallet e-value held in equivalent fiat currency in a custodian commercial bank account. The legal status of this custodian account and attribution of interest earned on the account are both the object of dispute between stakeholders (telecommunication companies, commercial banks, consumers) and are targets of increasing regulatory intervention. These research findings are generalizable insofar as the issue of float value and float management is beginning to be scrutinized as a blind spot in the regulation of digital financial platforms across the globe. Secondly, value is generated by reducing the cost of financial transactions. Because the African continent is a “soft currency” context, where currency convertibility is constrained, there are very significant costs associated with foreign transactions. The research indicates that a primary motivation for local stakeholders is to leverage fintech platforms to overcome the negative consequences of soft currency economies. Mobile wallet transactions, which include both international and intra-African remittances, reduce costs dramatically, often by circumventing international clearing systems (e.g., SWIFT). Stakeholders therefore see the potential for digital payment platforms to create the conditions for de-linking local currencies from dollar-denominated clearing. This aspiration for many local financial actors reiterates international policy positions that seek to facilitate bond issuance in local currencies in keeping with the sustainable finance goals articulated in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

The research project achieved its broader impact goals by consolidating collaborations with local institutions. The latter include the Ghana Institute of Management and Public Administration, the University of Ghana Business School, and the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology. Collaboration entailed research design (surveys, focus groups), seminars, and training of research assistants, including an IMF Youth Fellow now enrolled as a doctoral student at the Booth School of Business, University of Chicago. Likewise, broader impact goals were achieved through the dissemination of the research findings through academic publications (3 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 book chapters, postings to online fora) and over 20 public presentations in Australia, Belgium, Denmark, France, South Africa, and the United States. Lastly, an international conference (“Digital Platform Economies: Value from Data?” New York, April 2024) was convened to showcase programmatic research on digital platforms and valuation processes.
